BHP's governance structure comprises the Board, the Nomination and Governance Committee, the Risk and Audit Committee, the Sustainability Committee, and the People and Remuneration Committee.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: BHP adopts a structured and rigorous approach to Board succession planning to guard against unforeseen departures, facilitate the orderly replacement of current Directors and oversee the development of a diverse pipeline. This continuous process allows the Board to ensure the right balance between experience and fresh perspectives, and the Board continues to be fit for purpose.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: The Board Governance Document outlines the Board's responsibilities and processes, including the matters specifically reserved for the Board, the authority delegated to the CEO and the accountability of the CEO for that authority, and guidance on the management of the relationship between the Board and the CEO. The Board Governance Document was updated in FY2023 as part of the governance review effective 1 July 2023.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: Upon appointment, each new Non-executive Director undertakes an induction program tailored to their needs. Non-executive Directors also undertake an induction program when they join a new Committee, tailored to the areas specific to that Committee's role and the Director's previous experience. Following the induction program, Non-executive Directors participate in continuous improvement activities through a training and development program, which the Nomination and Governance Committee oversees to help ensure that Directors, individually and collectively, develop and maintain the skills and knowledge to assist them in performing their role effectively.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: BHP adopted an Inclusion and Diversity Position Statement, which sets out its diversity policy and priorities to accelerate the development of a more inclusive work environment and to enhance overall workplace diversity. BHP aspires to achieve gender balance on the Board, among its senior executives and across its workforce by FY2025. BHP defines gender balance as a minimum of 40 per cent women and 40 per cent men, in line with the definitions used by entities such as the International Labour Organisation.

column13: A determination of independence is carried out upon a Director's appointment, annually, and at any other time where the change in circumstances of a Director warrants reconsideration. Some Directors hold or have previously held positions in companies with which BHP has commercial relationships. The Board has assessed the relationships between BHP and the companies in which Directors hold positions. It has concluded that the relationships do not interfere with the Directors' exercise of objective, unfettered or independent judgement or their ability to act in the best interests of BHP.

column13: BHP's Code of Conduct is approved by the Board and is based on its Charter values of Sustainability, Integrity, Respect, Performance, Simplicity and Accountability. It applies to all BHP's Directors, senior executives and employees. BHP's Code of Conduct includes its policies on speaking up and anti-bribery and corruption, sets out standards of behaviour for its people and is an important statement of the culture at BHP.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: The Board maintains a skills matrix that identifies the skills and experience the Board needs for the next period of BHP's development, considering BHP's circumstances and the changing external environment. The Board skills matrix identifies the future-facing skills the Board intends to build, acquire and retain over the medium term in anticipation of its needs as it pursues its strategy of securing growth options in future-facing commodities. The Board skills matrix not only indicates the skills the Board currently possesses but also illustrates the new skills the Board intends to acquire and indicates the preferred manner in which it intends to acquire them.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: An external board evaluation was conducted approximately every three years in FY2023. The evaluation assessed the performance of the Board as a whole and its Committees. The scope of the review included Board and Committee performance and effectiveness. It considered the balance of skills, experience, independence and knowledge of the Group on the Board, its diversity and culture, and the operation of governance processes.

column7: The remuneration received each year depends on the achievement of business and individual performance measures that generate sustained shareholder value.

During FY2023, the Remuneration Committee's role involved overseeing and monitoring the remuneration framework and practices (including the adoption of incentive plans and levels of reward for the CEO and other ELT members) and compliance with remuneration-related requirements, as well as important functions relating to people, such as the review, at least annually, of remuneration by gender.
For FY2024, the Committee determined that the CEO's base salary would increase by 4 per cent, effective 1 September 2023.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: BHP has mechanisms for anyone to raise a query about its Code of Conduct or make a report if they feel the Code of Conduct has been breached. EthicsPoint is BHP's 24-hour confidential reporting tool for reporting misconduct. It can be used by employees, contractors, external partners and stakeholders, including members of the public, to raise concerns about misconduct that has either happened to them or been witnessed. All reports received in EthicsPoint are reviewed and categorised by the Ethics team.
